name: Closure
statement: For all elements a and b in G, the product a * b is also in G.
philosophy: A group must be internally complete under its operation. This ensures that the operation never exits the structure.

name: Associativity
statement: For all elements a, b, and c in G, (a * b) * c = a * (b * c).
formal: ∀a, b, c ∈ G, (a * b) * c = a * (b * c)
philosophy: Associativity ensures that the order of operations does not matter when chaining elements. This is key to simplification and composition.

name: Identity element
statement: There exists an identity element e in G such that for all elements a in G, e * a = a * e = a.
formal: ∃e ∈ G, ∀a ∈ G, e * a = a ∧ a * e = a
philosophy: The identity element acts as a neutral element in the group. Its presence allows reversibility and simplification.

name: Inverse element
statement: For each element a in G, there exists an element b in G such that a * b = b * a = e.
formal: ∀a ∈ G, ∃b ∈ G, a * b = e ∧ b * a = e
philosophy: Inverses guarantee that every action has a counteraction, creating symmetry and enabling solving of equations within the group.
